 THIS CRL.P COMING ON FOR ORDERS, THROUGH VIDEO CONFERENCE, THIS DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING:

 ORDER

 Petitioner is the step-father of the victim aged about 13 years. FIR came to be registered against the petitioner based on the information lodged by Smt.Gunasheela, attached to Child Line, Bengaluru. In the complaint, it was alleged that the victim was studying in VII Standard at Nehru Centenary English School, Kanakanagar, Bengaluru. The parents of the victim were separated for the past five years and her mother got remarried to the petitioner/accused and was residing at Kanakanagar. The mother of the victim was an alcoholic and after she went to sleep, the petitioner/accused used to sexually abuse the victim for the past two years and threatened her not to disclose the same to anyone. In the complaint, it was stated that the victim narrated her plight to her friends and as per their advice, she called the Child Helpline and reported the matter to the complainant.

 2. Sri.Tomy Sebastian, learned Senior Counsel appearing for the petitioner contends that the victim in her statement given to the Magistrate under section 164 of Cr.P.C., has unequivocally stated that she was in love with a boy by name Sameer. Her father namely the petitioner/accused saw them and as she needed freedom, by mistake, her father was implicated. Learned Magistrate failed to consider this statement and has rejected the application filed by the petitioner solely on the ground that the offences alleged against the petitioner are severe and are punishable upto life imprisonment.

 3. Learned HCGP appearing for respondent however opposed the petition contending that the petitioner is involved in a serious offence under the provisions of POCSO Act and therefore he is not entitled for grant of bail.

 4. I have considered the submissions and have perused the records.

 5. The offences charged against the petitioner are punishable under sections 5(n) and 6 of POCSO Act, 2012 and under sections 376 and 506 of IPC. In the statement given by the victim under section 161 of Cr.P.C., the victim has categorically implicated the petitioner herein and has stated that after her mother used to go to sleep, after getting heavily drunk, the petitioner used to sexually abuse her since the past two years. She has also narrated that she herself informed the matter to the Child Helpline through the mobile phone of one Smt.Priya, mother of her classmate. The complainant has also narrated that on getting the information over the phone, she visited the school where the victim was studying and on ascertaining that she was a victim of sexual offence, lodged the report before the D.J. Halli Police, whereafter the victim was subjected to medical examination and the accused was also arrested and subjected to medical examination.

 6. The medical report produced along with the charge sheet indicates that as on the date of the examination of the victim, she was aged about 13 years. She had reached menarche. Her hymen was not intact. All these facts prima facie go to show that she was a victim of sexual assault. Unfortunately, in her statement given before the learned Magistrate under section 164 of Cr.P.C., the victim stated thus:

 "I have come to the court with my mother. I will give statement in front of my mother. I am aware of Kannada language very little and I can speak English. It is my mistake, first of all I did love with one boy Sameer. My father saw. I needed freedom to meet that boy. It all my mistake. I saw in T.V. about Hyderabad i.e., about Priyanka. I am feeling guilty. Its all of my mistake please leave my father. My father nothing he did I wanted freedom to meet them. Hence, I said to the police like that. That's all."

 Though this statement is contrary to the previous statements made by the victim before the Police and the complainant, yet, solely on that ground, the petitioner cannot be enlarged on bail as he is otherwise not entitled to bail having regard to the inter se relationship and the manner in which the victim is alleged to have been subjected to sexual offence. Though in her statement recorded under section 164 of Cr.P.C., she has stated that she was in love with Sameer, there is no material on record to show that she was sexually abused by him. No doubt, learned Magistrate has not adverted to the statement of the victim recorded under section 164 of Cr.P.C., but there being other evidence on record, it is not proper for this Court to jump to the conclusion that the statement made by the victim under section 164 of Cr.P.C. is truthful and free of any force or coercion. The circumstances that drove the victim to make contradictory statements before the Police as well as before the Magistrate needs to be enquired into. Likewise, the facts and circumstances which made the victim to implicate her father also are required to be determined, which could be done only in a free atmosphere free of lurking threat, coercion or influence by the petitioner or any other close relatives of the victim.

 7. Undeniably, the victim has been residing in the house of the petitioner/accused along with her mother. Under the said circumstances, if the petitioner is enlarged on bail at this juncture, possibility of the petitioner/accused threatening or influencing or prevailing upon the victim cannot be ruled out, which may prejudice the case of the prosecution and the possibility of ascertaining the actual truth will also be affected. Hence, I am of the view that until the victim is examined by the Trial Court, the petitioner cannot be admitted to bail.
 For the above reasons, the petition is rejected. However, having regard to the facts and circumstances narrated above, the Trial Court is directed to examine the victim as expeditiously as possible, preferably through Video Conference and in the event the victim stands by the statement made by her under section 164 Cr.P.C., the Trial court shall enlarge the petitioner on bail, on such terms and conditions as found expedient.

Akhtar Khan vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 14 July, 2023
Author: Rohit Arya

1
IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH AT GWALIOR CRA No. 1152 of 2023 (AKHTAR KHAN Vs THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH AND OTHERS)
Dated : 14-07-2023 Shri F.A. Shah- Advocate for the appellant. Dr. Anjali Gyanani - Public Prosecutor for respondent/State. Heard on I.A. No.7003 of 2023, which is first application under Section 389(1) Cr.P.C. filed on behalf of appellant-Akhtar Khan seeking suspension of sentence and grant of bail. Appellant-Akhtar Khan stood convicted under Section 4(2) of POCSO Act and sentenced to undergo 20 years' R.I. with a fine of Rs.2,000/- and under Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and sentenced to undergo 2 years' R.I with a fine of Rs.1,000/- with default stipulations vide judgment of conviction and order of sentence dated 15/12/2022 passed by Special Judge (POCSO Act), Shivpuri (M.P.) in Special Case No.124/2019. Present appellant so far has undergone incarceration of about 17 months in toto, as transpired during the course of hearing. Co-accused/Appellant No.1 in Criminal Appeal No.838 of 2023-Shakil Khan is the biological father of the prosecutrix as after the demise of his first wife and mother of the prosecutrix, he married to co-accused Shehnaz Bano. As per prosecution story, the prosecutrix claiming herself to be 14 years of age, on 20/09/2019, lodged an FIR to the effect that for the last 4-5 years since the time her mother expired, she was ill-treated by her step-mother Shehnaz Bano off and on. She, therefore, had left the house and started living with her grand-parents. Thereafter, on 1/1/2019, while she was staying with her maternal uncle's house, step-mother Shehnaz came there and against her wishes brought her back. Thereafter, she started searching for the match though she was not major. She manipulated her marriage (Nikah) with accused/appellant Akhtar and Farukh Khan had reduced in writing the process of Nikah. After so-called solemnization of marriage (Nikah), she was subjected to forcible sexual abuse against her wishes by Akhtar from 24/08/2019 to 28/08/2019. Thereafter, accused/appellant Akhtar called her grand-parents to the Kota Court and whereafter, signing of certain documents, she was given in custody of her grand-parents. Thereafter, she came back to her grand-parents' house from Kota. It is alleged that appellant Akhtar had also threatened the prosecutrix with dire consequences, if she divulged the factum of marriage and that of sexual abuse. In the aforesaid backdrop, the prosecutrix filed the complaint and the same was registered at Crime No.213/19. Based thereupon, investigation was set in motion. The Investigating Officer, upon collection of incriminating evidence, filed challan. The Special Court upon critical evaluation of the evidence placed on record convicted and sentenced the present appellant as aforesaid. Learned counsel for the appellant while taking exception to the impugned judgement submits that the prosecutrix in her statement before the Court has clearly stated that her date of birth is 11/10/2000 as recorded in Aadhar Card and therefore, she was major as on the date of incident. However, the trial Court in Para-20 of the judgement, ignored the same and relied upon her date of birth as per the certificate of the Municipal Corporation, Kota (Ex.P/10) as 11/10/2005. That apart, she has turned hostile and belied the story of prosecution. Shakil Khan, co-convict/appellant No.1 in Criminal Appeal No.838 of 2023, has already been admitted to suspension of sentence and grant of bail vide order dated 27.04.2023. On such grounds, learned counsel prays for suspension of sentence and grant of bail to the present appellant. Per contra, learned Public Prosecutor for respondent/State, while opposing the application supporting the judgment impugned submits that looking to the gravity of offence, no exception can be taken in the matter of suspension of sentence and grant of bail to the present appellant. Upon hearing learned counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains from commenting upon rival contentions touching merits of the case but regard being had to the fact that co-convict/appellant No.1 -Shakil Khan in Criminal Appeal No.838 of 2023 has already been admitted to suspension of sentence and grant of bail vide order dated 27.04.2023, the present appellant has so far undergone incarceration of 17 months in toto coupled with the fact that appeal is of the year 2023 and there is no likelihood of its early hearing in near future and therefore, in the obtaining facts and circumstances, we hereby extend the benefit of suspension of sentence and grant of bail to present appellant-Akhtar Khan. Accordingly, I.A.7003 of 2023 stands allowed and it is directed that the jail sentence of appellant-Akhtar Khan shall remain suspended during pendency of present appeal and he shall be released on bail, subject to verification of amount of fine being deposited and on his furnishing a personal bond in the sum of Rs.2,00,000/- (Rupees Two Lacs only) with one solvent surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of the Trial Court. Appellant-Akhtar Khan is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court first on 13.09.2023 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed by Office in this behalf. Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of disposal of the application for suspension of sentence and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal. Certified copy as per rules. (ROHIT ARYA) (SANJEEV S KALGAONKAR) JUDGE JUDGE pd

I heard the learned Public Prosecutor, who, on instructions, submits that the petitioner has no criminal antecedent and that the affidavit seeking quashing of the proceedings was submitted on her own volition. It is submitted that, though the sexual relationship of the petitioner with the victim was immediately prior to the victim becoming major, the fact that the petitioner had married the victim after she became a major and that both of them are leading a harmonious married life, can be taken into consideration. The applicant herein is the accused in Crime No.388 of 2018 of the Kilikolloor Police Station, registered under B' 354A of the IPC, B' 9(n) r/w. B' 10 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012, and also under B'75 of the Juvenile Justice (Care & Protection of Children) Act, 2015. 3. The de facto complainant is the mother of the survivor child, who is aged about 14 years and studying in the IX Standard. She alleged that her daughter was found missing on 11.6.2018 from school. A crime was registered under Section 57 of the Kerala Police Act, 2011. The minor child was traced out later. She disclosed that she was in love with a boy and she had eloped with him. She also disclosed that she has had an active sexual relationship with the said boy, who is aged 19 years. In the said statement, she also disclosed that the applicant herein, who is her step-father, has touched her breasts with sexual intent on more than one occasion. On these allegations, two Crimes were registered. Crime No.387 of 2018 was registered against her 19 year old lover under B'B' 366 and 376(2)(n) of the IPC and under B' 5(1) r/w. B' 6 of the POCSO Act, 2012. Immediately thereafter, the instant crime was registered against the applicant for sexually harassing the child. 4. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submitted that he has been implicated as his step-daughter felt that he was responsible for the arrest and detention of her lover. As the child was quite young, the applicant herein along with his wife had strongly opposed the relationship that she had with the accused in Crime No.387 of 2018. It is contended that after the death of the father of the minor child about three years back, the applicant has married her mother and he has been caring and protecting the family. Finally, it is submitted that the applicant has been in custody from 12.6.2018 and prays that orders for his release be issued. 5. Heard the learned Public Prosecutor, who has opposed the prayer. It is submitted that the medical examination report of the child shows that she has been subjected to penetrative sexual assault by the 1st accused. It is further submitted that the child has unequivocally stated that the applicant herein had abused her on more than one occasions. 6. I have considered the submissions advanced and have gone through the case diary. It appears that the applicant herein has been residing with the family after marrying the mother for the past more than two years. Allegations have been levelled against him only after registration of the crime against the lover of the child. The contention of the learned counsel that he has been implicated for his exuberance in prosecuting the lover of the survivor cannot be ruled out at this stage. Furthermore, serious allegations are levelled against the 1 st accused. The investigation appears to have progressed much and in the facts and circumstances further detention in custody of the applicant may not serve any purpose. By imposing appropriate conditions, for safeguarding the interest of the prosecution as well as the protection of the minor child, the applicant can now be released. 7. In the result, this application will stand allowed. The applicant shall be released on bail on his executing a bond for Rs.1,00,000/-(Rupees one lakh only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the court having jurisdiction. The above order shall be subject to the following conditions: 1). The applicant shall appear before the Investigating Officer on all Saturdays between 10 a.m. and 1.00 p.m., for 3 months or till final report is filed, whichever is earlier. 2). He shall not enter the limits of Kilikkolloor Police Station for a period of six months except for complying with the conditions of this order. If for any extraordinary reason the applicant requires to enter the limits, previous permission has to be obtained from the jurisdictional Court. 3). He shall not intimidate or attempt to influence the witnesses; nor shall he tamper with the evidence. He shall not contact the victim or her family members. 4). He shall not commit any offence while he is on bail. 5). He shall not leave India without the permission of the Court and if having passport, shall deposit the same before the Trial Court within a week; If release of the passport is required at a later period, he shall be at liberty to move appropriate application before the Court having jurisdiction. In case of violation of any of the above conditions, the jurisdictional Court shall be empowered to consider the application for cancellation, if any, and pass appropriate orders in accordance with the law. Sec.75 provides punishment for cruelty to child. In order to attract Sec.75, the offender must be a person who is in actual charge of or control over the victim child. I do not consider the present case to be one where custodial interrogation of the petitioner is an absolute must for an effective investigation of the case. Considering all these matters, I am inclined to grant him bail. The application is allowed. The petitioner shall not intimidate or try to influence witnesses. He shall not destroy or tamper with evidence. The court having jurisdiction is hereby empowered to cancel the bail in accordance with law if any of the conditions mentioned above is violated. If the petitioner surrenders before the court concerned, this order will cease to have effect and the said court will pass appropriate orders as if this order has not been passed. A.M.BABU 03/04/19 JUDGE

Passage: Xxxxxx vs State Of Kerala on 6 February, 2025. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT THE HONOURABLE MRS. JUSTICE C.S. SUDHA Thursday, the 6th day of February 2025 / 17th Magha, 1946 CRL.M.APPL.NO.1/2022 IN CRL.A NO.907 OF 2022 SC 35/2017 OF THE (FAST TRACK) SPECIAL COURT, THRISSUR PETITIONERS/APPELLANT: XXX RESPONDENT/RESPONDENT: STATE OF KERALA REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROCECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, KOCHIN, PIN - 682031. Application praying that in the circumstances stated therein the High Court be pleased to suspend the sentence in SC No.35/2017 on the files of the Special Judge's Court (POCSO), Thrissur. If the sentence is not so suspended, the petitioner would be put to irreparable injuries and hardships. On the other hand, no prejudice will be caused to any of the respondent if the sentence is so suspended. This Application coming on for orders upon perusing the application and upon hearing the arguments of M/S.SARATH BABU KOTTAKKAL, REBIN VINCENT GRALAN, Advocates for the petitioner and of PUBLIC PROSECUTOR for the respondent, the court passed the following: C.S.SUDHA, J. -------------------------------------------------------------- Crl.M.Appl. No.1 of 2022 in Crl. Appeal No.907 of 2022 --------------------------------------------------------------- Dated this the 6th day of February 2025 ORDER This application under Section 389 Cr.P.C. has been filed seeking suspension of sentence of the applicant/accused in S.C.No.35 of 2017 on the file of the Special Judge's Court (PoCSO), Thrissur. He has been found guilty of the offences punishable under Sections 6 read with 5(l) and (m) of the PoCSO Act and Sections 342 and 376(2)(i) IPC. He has been sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment for the aforesaid offences. The sentences have been directed to run concurrently. The maximum period of imprisonment he will have to undergo is 20 years. It is submitted by the learned counsel for the applicant/accused that there are several inconsistencies in the statements as well as in the testimony of PW2, the victim, as well as PW1, her mother who had given Ext.P1 FIS. It is pointed out that the case of penetrative sexual assault is not supported by the medical evidence. It is also pointed out that there is no consistent evidence relating to the date of the alleged incident. In addition to the aforesaid aspects, it is also pointed out that the applicant/accused is a 75 year old man suffering from Hydrocele and Bradycardia and that he requires surgery. Earlier, he was granted interim bail for a period of one month for the purpose of undergoing surgery. However, as his blood pressure could not be brought under control, the surgery could not take place and hence on medical grounds also the suspension is sought for. The learned public prosecutor opposes the application and submits that the victim child, who was only 10 years old, has clearly deposed before the court that she was unable to recall the date on which the incidents of abuse took place. However, she has clearly deposed that on three different occasions, the accused herein had committed digital rape on her. This probably must be the reason why she was unable to recollect the exact dates on which the incident took place. The learned public prosecutor also draws my attention to the testimony of PW4, a consultant pediatrician, Sun Hospital, Thrissur, to substantiate the argument that the medical evidence is also there to support the prosecution story. Heard both sides. I was taken through Ext.P1 FIS as well as the testimony of PW2, the victim; PW1, the mother and PW9, the doctor who examined the victim child on 24/11/2016. Ext.P1 FIS is seen given by the mother on 24/11/2016. In the FIS, the allegation is that the incident of abuse took place on 22/11/2016. According to the testimony of PW1, the mother, the incident took place on 24/11/2016 and it was on the same day she had taken PW2 to the hospital as she had seen injuries on the private parts as well as a hair inside the mouth of PW2. However PW9, the doctor who examined the child on 24/11/2016 in Ext.P6 medical certificate records that there was no external injury. As far as the testimony of PW4 is concerned, it is seen that there are absolutely no records to support his testimony that he had examined the child sometime in November 2016. It is also brought to my notice that the victim child had stated in her 161 statement that the incident took place on 23/11/2016 whereas in her chief examination, her testimony was that the incident took place on 22/11/2016. This contradiction was brought out in her examination and proved through the testimony of PW6 and the same has been marked as Ext.D2. On going through the testimony of the material prosecution witnesses, I think that the learned counsel for the applicant/accused is justified in arguing that there are inconsistencies in the testimonies and that doubts arise from the materials on record. It appears that the applicant/accused has got a good arguable case and therefore in the aforesaid circumstances and on medical ground, the sentence of the applicant/accused is suspended till the disposal of the appeal. It is submitted that the fine amount has already been deposited before the trial court. Hence, the sentence imposed on the applicant/accused is suspended on the following conditions: i) The applicant/accused shall be released on bail on executing a bond for ₹50,000/- (Rupees fifty thousand only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the trial court; ii) He shall not in any way contact or attempt to contact the victim or family member(s) in any manner; iii) He shall not commit any offence(s) while on bail; iv) If the conviction and sentence of the applicant is upheld or even modified, the time during which he is so released shall be excluded in computing the term of his sentence as provided in Section 430(4) BNSS; v) It is also made clear that if any of the conditions are violated, the bail shall stand cancelled. Post on 27/10/2025. Sd/- C.S.SUDHA JUDGE Jms 06-02-2025 /True Copy/ Assistant Registrar

Today, when the matter was taken up for hearing a joint Memo of Compromise filed before this Court signed by the petitioner and the second respondent and their respective counsels. The petitioner and the second respondent present before this Court, identified by Ms.S.Bagavathy, WSSI, AWPS, Palayamkottai, Tirunelveli City, as well as by the learned counsels appearing for the parties. This Court enquired both the parties, satisfied that the parties have come to an amicable settlement between themselves on their own voluntarily without any compulsion. The second respondent had stated that she and the petitioner are husband and wife and considering their children' future, she intends to withdraw the complaint against the petitioner. She has also filed filed an affidavit. The relevant portion of the affidavit reads as follows: “ ............4. It is submitted that the petitioner herein is my husband, out of wedlock we have blessed with one male and one female child. During my matrimonial life some misunderstanding were arose between I and the petitioner. Therefore, I lodged complaint against the petitioner. Now by taking consideration of the future life of our children I and the petitioner amicably settle the entire issue without making any allegations each other. As a result, I show my intent to drop the criminal proceedings pending against the petitioner herein. In view of the same, I have no objection to quash the FIR in Crime NO.31 of 2024 on the file of the first respondent dated 22.07.2024.............”. The case has been registered for offences under Sections 11(1) and 12 of Protection of Child from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. It is settled law that the High Court has inherent power under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to quash the criminal proceedings even for the offences which are not compoundable under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, where the parties have settled their dispute between themselves. However, while quashing the criminal proceedings, based on the settlement arrived at between the parties, the High Court should act with caution and the power should be exercised sparingly only in order to secure the ends of justice and also to prevent abuse of process of any Court. The legal position expressed by the Hon'ble Apex Court in the case of Gian Singh vs. State of Punjab and another reported in (2012) 10 SCC 303 and Parbatbhai Aahir @ Parbatbhai Vs. State of Gujarat) reported in (2017) 9 SCC 641 were taken into consideration. Keeping the above principles in mind, let us now consider the instant case as to whether it is a fit case to quash the criminal proceedings based on the settlement arrived at between the parties. In the case at hand, though FIR has been registered for the offences punishable under Sections 11(1) and 12 of Protection of Child from Sexual Offences Act, 2012, now, the petitioner and the second respondent have amicably settled their dispute between themselves. The second respondent has also filed an affidavit. The dispute between husband and wife has been magnified and stamped as an POCSO offence. The victim is minor daughter. Now, all are residing together as a family happily. In view of the compromise between the parties, the possibility of conviction is also remote and bleak. In the above circumstances, continuity of the criminal proceedings would only cause oppression and prejudice to the parties, hence, in order to secure the ends of justice, this Court is inclined to quash the criminal proceedings. Accordingly, this Criminal Original Petition is allowed and FIR in Crime No.31 of 2024 registered against the petitioner on the file of the first respondent, is hereby quashed and the terms of joint compromise memo and affidavit filed by the second respondent shall form part and parcel of this order.

The survivor in the instant case is the daughter of Sri.Madhu M.R., the elder brother of the applicant, who died on 26.11.2016 after a prolonged bout of illness. Sri.Madhu M.R. had divorced his wife in the year 2012 and thereafter, the children were allegedly residing with their father. After the death of Sri.Madhu M.R., a petition was filed before the Judicial Magistrate, Paravur by the survivor and her mother seeking a residence order under Section 12 of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The respondents in the said petition are the applicant and his aged mother. In the said petition, which was filed in the year 2017, among other allegations, it was stated that the child and her brother were residing with their father till his death. While her father was not at home, the applicant and his friends used to behave in a salacious manner and used to look at the child with lustful eyes. Though she used to complain to her grandmother, instead of reprimanding the 1st accused, the victim used to be physically abused. On these allegations, a prayer was made to permit her mother to reside in the parental home of the father of the victim. On receipt of the said application, the learned Magistrate noticed that the petition contained allegations of sexual abuse on a minor child and decided to report the offence as envisaged under Section 19 of the POCSO Act. On receipt of the said memorandum dated 4.9.2018, a Crime was registered as aforesaid. The statement of the child was recorded by the Sub Inspector of Police, Women Cell. In her statement, which was recorded on 6.9.2018, she levelled very serious allegations against the applicant. She stated that on October, 2016 while she was not at home, the applicant came and sat next to her and touched her body with sexual intent. She spurned his advances and went to her room. He is alleged to have entered her bedroom and subjected her to penetrative sexual intercourse. After committing the act, he left the room. According to the child, though she narrated all these aspects to her father, he did not believe her words. The applicant herein was arrested on 19.9.2018 and he remains in custody. 4. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submitted that this is a classic case of abuse of provisions of the Act. In the petition filed seeking relief under the Domestic Violence Act, all that the child had stated was that the applicant used to behave in an inappropriate manner. She did not even have a case that the applicant touched her body let alone commit sexual intercourse. The learned Magistrate, thereafter considered the application and refused the prayer for a residence order. According to the learned counsel, the father of the child was extremely sick and neither the mother nor the children used to visit him. If there was any truth in the allegations, nothing prevented the mother or the child to level such allegations in the application filed before the learned Magistrate. The learned counsel has referred to Annexure-I petition filed under the Domestic Violence Act and Annexure-II order passed by the learned Magistrate. 5. Heard the learned Public Prosecutor and I have gone through the case diary. 6. He shall not commit any offence while on bail. 4). In case of violation of any of the above conditions, the jurisdictional Court shall be empowered to consider the application for cancellation, if any, and pass appropriate orders in accordance with the law. Sessions Judge, Vijayapur, at Vijayapur in Special Case (POSCO) No. 21/2014, and acquit the appellant in the said case. This appeal is coming on for admission this day, the Court delivered the following: JUDGMENT The accused in Special Case (POCSO) No.21/2014 on the file of II Addl. Sessions Judge, Vijaypur has come up in this appeal challenging the order of conviction and sentence. In the proceedings before Session's Court, charge sheet was filed against the appellant herein for the offence punishable U/Sec.3(a) (b), 4, 5(m) and 6 of Protection of the Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and U/Sec.376(f) of Indian Penal Code. The aforesaid charge sheet is filed based on a complaint wherein it is stated that on 6.1.2014 appellant herein is said to have sexually abused victim girl CW-4 namely Sujata who is aged about 8 years and resident of Ingalagi Tanda. On the ill-fated day when she had gone to attend nature call at about 6.15 p.m., in the evening, by luring the said child with chocolates and biscuits accused forcibly took her into the field of one Kulkarni wherein Jawar crop was standing. The accused is said to have made the child to lay on the ground, removed her under garment and slept on her. It is also accused that he inserted his finger into her vagina, pressed in it and bit her lips and subsequently committed rape on her. A complaint was filed in this behalf, wherein, investigation was conducted and thereafter charge sheet was filed and the matter was committed to Sessions wherein cognizance for the offence was taken on 18.7.2014. After the charges are framed, same was read over to him. Since he pleaded not guilty, matter was taken up for trial. On behalf of prosecution, in all 17 witnesses are examined and 26 documents are marked. The material objects produced at MOs-1 to 5 are also taken into consideration. In the Court below, P.Ws.6 and 8 are the parent of victim girl. It is seen that P.Ws.9, 10, 11 and 12 have turned hostile and did not support the prosecution. Even P.Ws.1 and 7 panch witnesses to the spot panchanama Ex.P-1 and seizure panchanama Ex.P-2 except admitting their signature on said panchanamas, they have not supported the case. Therefore, in the Court below, they were treated as hostile witnesses and they were subjected to cross examination by prosecution. It is seen, in this proceedings that even the complainant - father of victim himself has turned hostile. However, after he was subjected to cross examination, the learned Session's Judge was able to elicit from him and as well as other witnesses that the injuries suffered by the child P.W.2 Sujata to her private part is not due to fall in the field and it is due to heinous act committed by the accused. On going through the judgment impugned, it is clearly seen that the prosecution and learned Sessions Judge has taken enormous strain to see that the truth is elicited from the victim as well as her family members to reconstruct the whole incident to bring the guilt of accused to the books, when all of them conspired together to bury the truth either for fear of shame in the society or fearing retaliatory action from the accused. On giving careful consideration to the entire judgment of the Court below, one thing is clear that the manner in which the entire prosecution has sought to be suppressed not only by the witnesses but also by the family members considering the future of the victim girl who is aged about 8 years, this Court is sympathetic to the family of the victim who have not supported the prosecution, who have given false evidence against the interest of their own child who is victim of sexual abuse. In any event, with proper appreciation of material on record, the Session's Court has been able to bring the accused to books and convict him for the offences punishable under the aforesaid provisions. On careful consideration of the judgement impugned as well as the material available in the form of evidence of the witnesses more particularly their cross examination, it is clearly seen that no grounds are made out by the accused in Spl.Case (POCSO) No.21/2014 to convert the finding of Session's Court in the aforesaid judgment to convert the conviction to an acquittal and also to disturb the sentence imposed on him. In fact this Court feels that considering the nature of offences, the punishment imposed is liberal one. In any event, since there is no appeal on behalf of the prosecution challenging the sentence disturbing the sentence does not arise. Accordingly, this appeal filed by the accused is hereby dismissed.

Learned counsel for the appellant at the first instance fairly submits that the appellant (juvenile) has already suffered the jail incarceration for almost three years. There is no allegation of either violating the personal liberty of the prosecutrix or committing rape. Instead, the sole allegation against him is that he entered the house and was standing outside the room, where she was sexually abused by the main accused Jitendra. This Criminal Petition is filed under Section 439 of Cr.P.C., praying to enlarge the petitioner on bail in Spl. Case NO.12/2017 in Crime No.73/2016 of Mahila Police Station,
Kalaburagi, which is registered for the offences punishable under Sections 363, 376(2)(n) of IPC and Sections 4, 6, 7, 11 and 12 of POCSO Act and also Section 10 of Child Marriage
Restraint Act. Brief facts leading to filing of the complaint are that, on 20.04.2016 at about 7.00 p.m. as the complainant was in her house and there was nobody in the house, petitioner came to the house of the victim, threatened and kidnapped her and thereafter he took her to his uncle's house at Kalaburagi. On 02.05.2016, the sister of the accused Roopa, Mahadevi and uncle Sharanappa all together took her to Nagavi Yallamma temple at Chittapur Taluka and there they solemnized the marriage of the victim with accused forcibly. Thereafter, accused kept the victim girl in his house at Kalaburagi and there he forcibly had sexual intercourse with her and the mother of the accused also helped the accused by way of abusing him to keep her in the house. It is further alleged that accused used to sexually harass her and used to have forcible sexual intercourse with her. With the help of others, she escaped and subsequently on 14.12.2016 she filed a written complaint. On the basis of the said complaint, a case has been registered against the accused persons. I have heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Additional State Public Prosecutor appearing for respondent-State. The main grounds urged by the learned counsel for the petitioner are that the complaint is baseless and there is a delay in filing the complaint. The said complaint has been filed only with an intention to harass the petitioner. It is also contended that no marriage as alleged in the complaint has been taken place. It is also contended that already charge-sheet has been filed and the remaining accused persons have not been shown as accused. It is further contended that the medical certificate reveals that there is no offence as alleged in the complaint and there are no external injuries found on the victim girl. It is further contended that if the petitioner is detained in custody, it is going to affect his right. Further, it is contended that the petitioner is the permanent resident of Kalaburagi and he is the sole earning member. Further, it is contended that if the petitioner is released on bail, he is ready to abide by the conditions to be imposed by this Court and ready to offer sureties. On these grounds, he prays for allowing the petition. On the contrary, learned Additional State Public Prosecutor appearing for the respondent-State would contend that the petitioner by kidnapping the victim, forcibly got married and thereafter he had sexual assault on a minor girl, who is aged about 16 years. He would also contend that the victim girl has given statement before the Magistrate and the same has been recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. and the learned Magistrate has also been shown as a party to the witness. He would further contend that in the statement of the victim, she has been categorically deposed that the petitioner has threatened and thereafter he had sexually assaulted her. He would further contend that because of the threat and other things the complaint was filed belatedly. At this juncture, if the petitioner is released on bail, he may tamper with the prosecution witnesses, he may abscond and he may not be available for trial. On these grounds, he prays for dismissal of the petition. I have gone through the copy of the complaint and other material produced along with the petition. By going through the contents of the complaint and other material, it indicates that the petitioner had kidnapped the victim on 20.04.2016, thereafter he got married her forcibly on 02.05.2016 and thereafter by threatening her he harassed her sexually and had a sexual intercourse with her. If the medical certificate is perused, it indicates that there is sexual assault has been made on the victim girl. Though the learned counsel for the petitioner would contend that there are no external injuries and other signs of sexual assault, but by going through the statement of the victim recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. and the medical certificate, they corroborate with the sexual assault committed by the petitioner. When the petitioner has committed a sexual assault on a minor girl, under such circumstances, the said offence is considered to be serious and he does not deserve any consideration. As such, the bail petition stands dismissed. However, since the petitioner is in custody, the Trial Court is directed to expedite the matter.

Except suggestions by the appellant, there is no evidence or circumstance to even remotely probabilise the defence plea. Accordingly, the learned Senior Public Prosecutor would submit that the findings of the trial court are quite convincing and devoid of any infirmity. 18. Decisions of the Apex Court which dealt with the question concerning reliability of the victim of a sexual offence have been encapsulated by a Division Bench of this Court in the judgment in Christopher (supra). The relevant part of that judgment is extracted below: 
 "26. In Nirmal Premkumar and another v. State, represented  by Inspector of Police  [(2024) SCC OnLine SC 260], the Apex Court while elucidating the principles that are to be borne in mind while appreciating oral testimony, it was observed as under in paragraph No. 11 of the judgment: 
 "11. Law is well settled that generally speaking, oral testimony may be classified into three categories, viz. : (i) wholly reliable; (ii) wholly unreliable; (iii) neither wholly reliable nor wholly unreliable. The first two category of cases may not pose serious difficulty for the Court in arriving at its conclusion(s). However, in the third category of cases, the Court has to be circumspect and look for corroboration of any material particulars by reliable testimony, direct or circumstantial, as a requirement of the rule of prudence." 27. In State of H.P. v. Raghubir Singh [(1993) 2 SCC 622] , the Apex Court held that there is no legal compulsion to look for any other evidence to corroborate the evidence of the prosecutrix before recording an order of conviction. Evidence has to be weighed and not counted. Conviction can be recorded on the sole testimony of the prosecutrix if her evidence inspires confidence and there is absence of circumstances which militate against her veracity. 28. In Rai Sandeep v. State (NCT of Delhi) [(2012) 8 SCC 21], under what circumstances can a witness be categorized as a sterling witness, the Apex Court had held as under: 
 "22. In our considered opinion, the 'sterling witness' should be of a very high quality and calibre whose version should, therefore, be unassailable. The court considering the version of such witness should be in a position to accept it for its face value without any hesitation. To test the quality of such a witness, the status of the witness would be immaterial and what would be relevant is the truthfulness of the statement made by such a witness. What would be more relevant would be the consistency of the statement right from the starting point till the end, namely, at the time when the witness makes the initial statement and ultimately before the court. It should be natural and consistent with the case of the prosecution qua the accused. There should not be any prevarication in the version of such a witness. The witness should be in a position to withstand the cross-examination of any length and howsoever strenuous it may be and under no circumstance should give room for any doubt as to the factum of the occurrence, the persons involved, as well as the sequence of it. Such a version should have co-relation with each and every one of other supporting material such as the recoveries made, the weapons used, the manner of offence committed, the scientific evidence and the expert opinion. The said version should consistently match with the version of every other witness. It can even be stated that it should be akin to the test applied in the case of circumstantial evidence where there should not be any missing link in the chain of circumstances to hold the accused guilty of the offence alleged against him. Only if the version of such a witness qualifies the above test as well as all other such similar tests to be applied, can it be held that such a witness can be called as a 'sterling witness' whose version can be accepted by the court without any corroboration and based on which the guilty can be punished. To be more precise, the version of the said witness on the core spectrum of the crime should remain intact while all other attendant materials, namely, oral, documentary and material objects should match the said version in material particulars in order to enable the court trying the offence to rely on the core version to sieve the other supporting materials for holding the offender guilty of the charge alleged. 29. In State of Maharashtra v. Chandraprakash Kewalchand Jain [(1990) 1 SCC 550], the Apex Court held that a woman, who is the victim of sexual assault, is not an accomplice to the crime but is a victim of another person's lust and, therefore, her evidence need not be tested with the same amount of suspicion as that of an accomplice. The Court observed as under in paragraph No.16: 
 "16. A prosecutrix of a sex offence cannot be put on a par with an accomplice. She is in fact a victim of the crime. The Evidence Act nowhere says that her evidence cannot be accepted unless it is corroborated in material particulars. She is undoubtedly a competent witness under Section 118 and her evidence must receive the same weight as is attached to an injured in cases of physical violence. The same degree of care and caution must attach in the evaluation of her evidence as in the case of an injured complainant or witness and no more. What is necessary is that the court must be alive to and conscious of the fact that it is dealing with the evidence of a person who is interested in the outcome of the charge levelled by her. If the court keeps this in mind and feels satisfied that it can act on the evidence of the prosecutrix, there is no rule of law or practice incorporated in the Evidence Act similar to Illustration (b) to Section 114 which requires it to look for corroboration. If for some reason the court is hesitant to place implicit reliance on the testimony of the prosecutrix it may look for evidence which may lend assurance to her testimony short of corroboration required in the case of an accomplice. The nature of evidence required to lend assurance to the testimony of the prosecutrix must necessarily depend on the facts and circumstances of each case. But if a prosecutrix is an adult and of full understanding the court is entitled to base a conviction on her evidence unless the same is shown to be infirm and not trustworthy. If the totality of the circumstances appearing on the record of the case disclose that the prosecutrix does not have a strong motive to falsely involve the person charged, the court should ordinarily have no hesitation in accepting her evidence." 30. In State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh[(1996) 2 SCC 384], the Apex Court held that in cases involving sexual harassment, molestation etc., the court is duty-bound to deal with such cases with utmost sensitivity. Minor contradictions or insignificant discrepancies in the statement of a prosecutrix should not be a ground for throwing out an otherwise reliable prosecution case. Evidence of the victim of sexual assault is enough for conviction and it does not require any corroboration unless there are compelling reasons for seeking corroboration. The court may look for some assurances of her statement to satisfy judicial conscience. The statement of the prosecutrix is more reliable than that of an injured witness as she is not an accomplice. The Court further held that the delay in filing FIR for sexual offence may not be even properly explained, but if found natural, the accused cannot be given any benefit thereof. The Court went on to observe as under in paragraph Nos. 8 & 21: 
 "8. .................... The court overlooked the situation in which a poor helpless minor girl had found herself in the company of three desperate young men who were threatening her and preventing her from raising any alarm. Again, if the investigating officer did not conduct the investigation properly or was negligent in not being able to trace out the driver or the car, how can that become a ground to discredit the testimony of the prosecutrix? The prosecutrix had no control over the investigating agency and the negligence of an investigating officer could not affect the credibility of the statement of the prosecutrix. ........................... The courts must, while evaluating evidence, remain alive to the fact that in a case of rape, no self-respecting woman would come forward in a court just to make a humiliating statement against her honour such as is involved in the commission of rape on her. In cases involving sexual molestation, supposed considerations which have no material effect on the veracity of the prosecution case or even discrepancies in the statement of the prosecutrix should not, unless the discrepancies are such which are of fatal nature, be allowed to throw out an otherwise reliable prosecution case. ......................................... Seeking corroboration of her statement before relying upon the same, as a rule, in such cases amounts to adding insult to injury. ................................ Corroboration as a condition for judicial reliance on the testimony of the prosecutrix is not a requirement of law but a guidance of prudence under given circumstances. xxxxx xxxxx xxxxxx 21. ............................ The courts should examine the broader probabilities of a case and not get swayed by minor contradictions or insignificant discrepancies in the statement of the prosecutrix, which are not of a fatal nature, to throw out an otherwise reliable prosecution case. If evidence of the prosecutrix inspires confidence, it must be relied upon without seeking corroboration of her statement in material particulars. If for some reason the court finds it difficult to place implicit reliance on her testimony, it may look for evidence which may lend assurance to her testimony, short of corroboration required in the case of an accomplice. The testimony of the prosecutrix must be appreciated in the background of the entire case and the trial court must be alive to its responsibility and be sensitive while dealing with cases involving sexual molestations. 32. In State of Orissa v. Thakara Besra [(2002) 9 SCC 86], the Apex Court held that rape is not mere physical assault, rather it often destroys the whole personality of the victim. The rapist degrades the very soul of the helpless female and, therefore, the testimony of the prosecutrix must be appreciated in the background of the entire case, and in such cases, non-examination even of other witnesses may not be a serious infirmity in the prosecution case, particularly where the witnesses had not seen the commission of the offence. 33. In Krishan Kumar Malik (supra), the Apex Court emphasized the duty of the court to differentiate between genuine cases from frivolous and concocted ones. It was held that the role of courts in such cases is to see whether the evidence available before the court is enough and cogent to prove the guilt of the accused. It was held as follows in paragraphs Nos. 31 and 32 of the judgment: 31. No doubt, it is true that to hold an accused guilty for commission of an offence of rape, the solitary evidence of the prosecutrix is sufficient provided the same inspires confidence and appears to be absolutely trustworthy, unblemished and should be of sterling quality. But, in the case in hand, the evidence of the prosecutrix, showing several lacunae, which have already been projected hereinabove, would go to show that her evidence does not fall in that category and cannot be relied upon to hold the appellant guilty of the said offences. 32. Indeed there are several significant variations in material facts in her Section 164 statement, Section 161 statement (CrPC), FIR and deposition in court. Thus, it was necessary to get her evidence corroborated independently, which they could have done either by examination of Ritu, her sister or Bimla Devi, who were present in the house at the time of her alleged abduction. The record shows that Bimla Devi though cited as a witness was not examined and later given up by the public prosecutor on the ground that she has been won over by the appellant. 33. After evaluating all the past precedents, the Apex Court in Nirmal Premkumar (supra) held that in cases where witnesses are neither wholly reliable nor wholly unreliable, the Court should strive to find out the true genesis of the incident. The Court can rely on the victim as a 'sterling witness' without further corroboration, but the quality and credibility must be exceptionally high. The statement of the prosecutrix ought to be consistent from the beginning to the end (minor inconsistencies excepted) from the initial statement to the oral testimony, without creating any doubt qua the prosecution's case. While a victim's testimony is usually enough for sexual offence cases, an unreliable or insufficient account from the prosecutrix, marked by identified flaws and gaps, could make it difficult for a conviction to be recorded.

No.90/2021. Appellant so far has undergone incarceration of three years and two months. A s per prosecution story, an FIR was lodged on 29.02.2020 by the prosecutrix accompanied by her parents and brother to the effect that on 26.01.2020 while her father was ill and her mother & sister had gone to the field and she was alone at the home, the present appellant, who was her neighbour, came to her house. He made false promise of marriage and thereafter manipulated her and she was subjected to sexual abuse. Besides, the appellant had taken her to Jhansi and went to take the ticket while leaving her at Jhansi platform. Thereafter, the prosecutrix came back home by traveling in the bus. On such allegations, the investigation was started. Upon completion of investigation, challan was filed and the case was committed to the Sessions Court for Trial. The Sessions Court after proper evaluation of evidence placed on record convicted and sentenced the appellant as mentioned above. Learned counsel for the appellant, while taking exception to the impugned judgment of conviction and order of sentence submits that the appellant is innocent and has been falsely implicated. It is a case of consent. The prosecutrix on her own volition had gone with the appellant. There is delay of one month in lodging of FIR. There is no medical evidence which supports the case of prosecution. As per Ex.D-5, medical ossification report, her age is 16-18 years. The prosecutrix's father PW-15 himself stated that date-of-birth of the prosecutrix was mentioned in the school record on hypothetical basis, for which they have no record. In the aforesaid circumstances, the impugned judgment is based on surmises and conjectures and suffers from vice of perversity. The appellant has already suffered incarceration of 3 years and 2 months. There is no likelihood of the early disposal of the appeal in the near future. Under such circumstances, learned counsel for the appellant prays that benefit of suspension of sentence may be extended to present appellant. Per contra, learned counsel for the State while supporting the impugned judgment opposes the suspension application and prays for its rejection with submission that the date-of-birth of the prosecutrix was 10.06.2007 and the incident took place on 26.01.2020 and thus, at that time she was 14 years of age, therefore, her consent is irrelevant. It is a case of manipulation and sexual abuse of a minor child at the hands of the present appellant. Hence no exception can be taken in the impugned judgment for suspension of sentence. Upon hearing learned counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains from commenting upon the rival contentions so advanced touching the merits of the case, but regard being had to the fact that that present appellant so far has suffered incarceration of 03 years and 02 months and there is no likelihood of early hearing of the appeal, in the obtaining facts and circumstances, appellant is held entitled to suspension of jail sentence. Accordingly, I.A.No.17030/2023 stands allowed and it is directed that jail sentence of appellant shall remain suspended during pendency of the present appeal and he shall be released on bail subject to verification of the factum of depositing the fine amount and on furnishing a personal bond in the sum of Rs.2,00,000/- (Rupees Two Lacs only) with one solvent surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of the Trial Court. He is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court first on 07.12.2023 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed in this behalf. Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of deciding the instant I.A. and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal. Passage: Jibitha vs Diyol on 28 January, 2020. The petitioner is the respondent in I.A.No.1162/2019 in GOP No.467/2019, on the file of Family Court, Trissur. The respondent in this original petition had filed the above application seeking interim custody of his minor son Dhanvin and permission to interact with his younger son Sidharth during holidays and vacation periods. In the application filed before the Family Court, the respondent had, inter alia, pleaded that, after the birth of the younger child, the petitioner refused to return to the matrimonial home. Subsequently, there was a mediation, and a rapprochement was effected. Immediately after conceiving the younger child, the petitioner went to her parental home and thereafter, has refused to resume co-habitation. The respondent is anxious to look after the welfare of the children, but the petitioner is not permitting the same. Therefore, interim custody of the older child may be given to him, and he be permitted to interact with the younger child. The application was opposed by the petitioner, who filed a written objection, inter alia, contending that the respondent is an alcoholic. Subsequent to the separation between them, there was a settlement before the Police, and the older child was agreed to be given on every Friday. However, the respondent's close friend Jayesh abused the child, and on a complaint by the petitioner, Crime No.93/2019 was registered by the Guruvayoor Police Station, for offences punishable under POCSO Act and under Section 377 of IPC against Jayesh. Hence custody of the child shall not be given to the petitioner. The petitioner hence prays that the application may be dismissed. The Family Court after considering the application and the counter filed, and also after interacting with the child, who did not raise any complaint against the father, held that by merely raising allegations of sexual assault against the respondent's friend, the respondent cannot be restricted from having interim custody and visitation rights of his children. Accordingly, the Family Court allowed I.A.No.1162/2019 by granting interim custody of the older child to the respondent from 11 a.m. of every 2nd Saturday till 3 p.m. on the following Sunday, with visitation right from 11 am to 1 pm on every 4th Sunday. Likewise, the respondent was permitted to interact with the younger child from 10 am to 11 am on every 2nd Saturday and from 11 am to 1 pm on every 4th Sunday. It is challenging the above order this original petition is filed under Article 227 of the Constitution of India, contending that the impugned order passed by the Family Court is erroneous and improper and is liable to be set aside. This Court in Suhara and Others v. Muhammed Jaleel [2019 (2) KLT 960] has held that, even if one of the parents is accused of an allegation in a crime under the POCSO Act, is no assurance to a Family court that the allegation is true. The Court has to consider the paramount welfare and interest of the child while granting custody of the child to such parent, and further that the registration of the crime is not a bar in granting the parent access and visitation right of the child. The Hon'ble Supreme Court in Anjali Kapoor vs. Rajiv Baijal [(2009) 7 SCC 322] has categorically declared the law that in a battle for custody of the child, Court should see what would best serve the welfare and interest of the child, which is the soul and predominant criteria and not the legal rights of the warring parents. In a most recent decision by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in Yashita Sahu vs State of Rajasthan and others [2020 SCC OnLine (SC) 50] rendered on 20.1.2020, has declared as follows: 'The child is the victim in custody battles. In this fight of egos and increasing acrimonious battles and litigations between two spouses, our experience shows that more often than not, the parents who otherwise love their child, present a picture as if the other spouse is a villain and he or she alone is entitled to the custody of the child. The court must therefore be very vary of what is said by each of the spouses. A child, especially a child of tender years requires the love, affection, company, protection of both parents. This is not only the requirement of the child but is his/her basic human right. Just because the parents are at war with each other, does not mean that the child should be denied the care, affection, love or protection of any one of the two parents. A child is not an inanimate object which can be tossed from one parent to the other. Every separation, every re-union may have a traumatic and psychosomatic impact on the child. Therefore, it is to be ensured that the court weighs each and every circumstance very carefully before deciding how and in what manner the custody of the child should be shared between both the parents. Even if the custody is given to one parent the other parent must have sufficient visitation rights to ensure that the child keeps in touch with the other parent and does not lose social, physical and psychological contact with any one of the two parents. It is only in extreme circumstances that one parent should be denied contact with the child. Reasons must be assigned if one parent is to be denied any visitation rights or contact with the child. Courts dealing with the custody matters must while deciding issues of custody clearly define the nature, manner and specifics of the visitation rights.' Undisputedly, in the present case the allegation is that, the respondent's friend and neighbour attempted to abuse the child and he is accused in POCSO case, therefore, the child shall not be given to the respondent. In view of the categoric declaration of law in the authoritative precedents cited supra, we are unable to accept the contentions that the handing over of the custody of the older child to the respondent would be detrimental to the paramount welfare and best interest of the older child, and that the respondent should be denied visitation rights of the younger child. The learned Judge of the Family Court had interacted with the older child and found that he has no complaint to go with his father and that there is no harm if the older child is being sent with the father on every 2nd Saturday till the following Sunday. Similarly, the father has been given visitation right to see the younger child also on every 2nd Saturday and 4th Sunday. The granting of interim custody and visitation rights would only benefit their paramount welfare and best interest. It is the welfare of the children that is to be looked into and not the rights and defences of the quarrelling parents. We do not find any ground warranting interference with the impugned order invoking the supervisory jurisdiction of this Court under Article 227 of the Constitution of India. The original petition is without merit. Accordingly, the Original Petition is dismissed.

O R D E R 1. Vide this order I shall decide the appeal filed on behalf of the appellant/CCL 'S' through his father against the order dated 13.01.2017 passed by the Ld. Juvenile Justice Board­II Delhi wherein the Ld. JJB has directed that medical opinion with regard to the age of the CCL/appellant be obtained by a duly constituted medical board at Safdarjung Hospital. 2. The appellant/CCL was apprehended by the police during the investigation of FIR No. 351/16, PS Lajpat Nagar which was initially registered U/s 307/34 IPC but subsequently due to death of the victim, Section 302 IPC was also added in the said case. 3. The appellant/CCL claimed juvenility and consequently age determination inquiry was conducted by the Ld. JJB­II. During the course of said inquiry it has come on record that after his apprehension the appellant/CCL had furnished his school documents in the nature of Scholar's register and transfer certificate Form purportedly issued from Chaudhary Beerpal Singh Inter College, Barah Bulandshahar, Uttar Pradesh. However the said document was found to be forged upon verification and subsequently yet another school record in the nature of school leaving certificate purportedly issued by Principal, Dhani Ram Sharma Public School, Makanpur Khadar, Post Dankaur District, Gautam Budh Nagar, Uttar Pradesh was filed alongwith bail application of appellant/CCL. In the age determination inquiry, the Ld. Board has examined CW­1, Principal of the said school and CW­2, Shri Harjit Panwar, Head Clerk, Transport Authority, Sheikh Sarai, New Delhi. The Ld. JJB also examined the appellant/CCL under section 165 Evidence Act wherein the CCL claimed that he had taken admission in Chaudhary Beerpal Singh Inter College, Barah Bulandshahar, Uttar Pradesh but he did not attend any classes. He was also examined in order to ascertain the documents on the basis of which he had set up his date of birth of 08.09.1992 before the Transport Authority at Delhi for procuring his driving licence but the Ld. Counsel for the CCL has contended that the said driving licence was procured through a tout/middle man. The Juvenile Justice Board placed reliance on the judgments titled, 'Om Prakash Vs. State of Rajasthan & Anr.','Parag Bhati Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh & Anr.' and other judgment titled 'Mukarrab Vs. State of UP' to hold that the plea of minority set up by the CCL is not free from ambiguity and doubts. The JJB directed for obtaining the medical opinion based on scientific investigations as regards age of CCL. 4. The Ld. counsel for appellant has vehemently argued that once the Juvenile Justice Board had examined CW­1, Principal of Dhani Ram Sharma Public School, Uttar Pradesh then there was no occasion for the JJB to order for constitution of medical board for seeking medical opinion in respect of the age of the appellant. 5. The Hon'ble Apex Court in 'Om Prakash vs. State of Rajasthan (Supra)' has decided about the approach to be adopted in age enquiry in grave and heinous offences and held that if there is a clear and unambiguous case in favour of the juvenile accused that he was a minor below the age of 18 years on the date of the incident, he would be entitled for this special protection under the Juvenile Justice Act. But when an accused commits a grave and heinous offence and attempts to take statutory shelter under the guise of being a minor, a casual or cavalier approach, cannot be permitted as the courts are enjoined upon to perform their duties with the object of protecting the confidence of common man in the institution entrusted with the administration of justice. 6. Thus in a circumstance where the Ld JJB cannot arrive at a conclusive finding regarding the age of the accused, the opinion of the medical experts based on x­ray and ossification test can be obtained. 7. The benefit of the principle of benevolent legislation attached to Juvenile Justice Act would thus apply to only such cases wherein the accused is held to be a juvenile based on cogent evidence regarding his minority as the benefit of the possibilities of two views regarding the age of the alleged accused involved in grave and serious offence cannot be allowed merely upon doubtful school admission record. 8. In view of the above discussions, the impugned order of the Ld. JJB for obtaining the medical opinion can not be faulted by appellant/CCL who gives forged and fabricated school documents regarding his age initially and also uses documents showing his majority for obtaining Driving Licence from Transport authority/Govt Dept but hides the said documents when involved in case of heinous nature.
Question: What implications arise from the findings and decisions of the JJB in the appeal of appellant/CCL 'S' concerning the age determination when the evidence presented was deemed inadequate? Discuss the role of scientific evidence in such cases.
A: The JJB must only use unverified documents presented by the appellant without gathering further evidence.
B: Judicial findings mandate a comprehensive medical examination when documentary evidence raises doubts regarding age.
C: The JJB can administer a verdict immediately without needing any evidence since the appellant claimed minority.
D: The JJB should solely rely on the appellant's account of his age without questioning its authenticity.
Correct Answer: Judicial findings mandate a comprehensive medical examination when documentary evidence raises doubts regarding age.
Reasoning: The passage indicates that due to the forged nature of school documents and doubts stemming from the appellant's age claims, the Juvenile Justice Board decided to seek medical opinion through scientific methods, reinforcing that adequate age determination hinges on reliable evidence rather than solely on the documents provided by the appellant.

The appellant filed this appeal questioning the conviction recorded under Section 366 of Indian Penal Code and sentenced to undergo seven years simple imprisonment. However, the appellant was acquitted for the charges under Sections 354-A, 366-A of Indian Penal Code and Section 12 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO' Act). 2. Briefly stated, the case of the prosecution is that PW1 who is brother of the victim PW4 filed complaint Ex.P1 with the police stating that PW4 was missing and he suspected the appellant herein. According to prosecution case, the appellant took PW4 to a temple and tied gold 'pustela thadu' (sacred thread) around the neck of bride during marriage ceremony. Thereafter, PW4 and the appellant stayed at different places and nearly after ten days, the accused and PW4 were caught by the police. Thereafter, statement of PW4 was recorded by the Magistrate and the police. As per the statement given to the police and Magistrate under under section 164 CRPC marked as Ex.P4, PW4 stated that she was in love with the appellant and decided to marry him and went with the appellant on her own, taking one gold biscuit weighing six tulas. She told the appellant that they should elope and get married, accordingly, they went to Karimnagar in an auto and boarded a bus for Secunderabad and from Secunderabad they went to Thirupathi. Thereafter, they were caught by the police. On completion of investigation, the police filed charge sheet under Sections 366-A, 354 of Indian Penal Code and Section 12 of the POCSO Act, 2012. After the trial, the learned Sessions Judge found the appellant not guilty for the said charges, however, convicted the appellant under Section 366 of Indian Penal Code. 3. It is the specific case of PW4-victim that she was in love with the appellant and on her own she went with the appellant to Karimnagar and to Thirupathi where they got married and came back to Secunderabad. Neither in the statement made before the Court nor the statement made before the Magistrate under Ex.P4, did PW4 make any allegation of force against the appellant. Further, she stated during the chief-examination that accused did not make any sexual assault on her. 4. The learned Sessions Judge found that the girl was not a minor and the provisions of Section of POCSO Act did not attract. The trial Court also found that there was no allegation of any molestation for which reason, the trial Court found the appellant not guilty for the said offences. 5. Section 366 of Indian Penal Code reads as follows: "366. Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc.--Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled, or knowing it to be likely that she will be compelled, to marry any person against her will, or in order that she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, or knowing it to be likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; 1 [and whoever, by means of criminal intimidation as defined in this Code or of abuse of authority or any other method of compulsion, induces any woman to go from any place with intent that she may be, or knowing that it is likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person shall also be punishable as aforesaid]." 6. Question of kidnapping or abducting does not arise when the evidence itself discloses that PW4 had taken six tulas of gold and asked the appellant to come along with him and on her own they went to Thirupathi and came back. There is not even a whisper for any kind of force or compulsion under which PW4 went along with the appellant for all the 15 days. 7. Having found that PW4 was not a child, having acquitted the appellant for the offences under POCSO Act and also having found that there was no outraging of modesty of victim girl, the trial Court ought to have acquitted the appellant. 8. As seen from the evidence none of the ingredients of Section 366 of the Indian Penal Code are made out and for the said reason, the appellant is liable to be acquitted of the charge under Section 366 of Indian Penal Code and accordingly, acquitted. The appeal is allowed setting aside the conviction of the appellant under Section 366 of IPC. Since the appellant is already on bail, the bail bonds shall stand cancelled. As a sequel thereto, miscellaneous petitions, if any, pending, shall stands closed.

Appellant stands convicted under Section 450 of IPC and sentenced to undergo 05 years RI with fine of Rs.500/-, under Section 328 of IPC and sentenced to undergo 05 years RI with fine of Rs.500/- and under Section 6 of POCSO Act read with Section 376(D) of IPC and sentenced to undergo 20 years' RI with fine of Rs.50,000/- with default stipulation vide judgment of conviction and order of sentence dated 01.08.2023 passed by the Special Judge (POCSO Act), Bhind (Madhya Pradesh) in Special Case (ST No.) No.80/2021. As per prosecution story, while parents of the prosecutrix had gone away to attend a marriage, her brother and sister were sleeping on the terrace and she was sleeping in the courtyard on the ground floor, on 11.05.2019, at about 12 in the intervening night, accused - Jitendra, Rohit and present appellant (juvenile) entered the house from terrace area and caught hold the prosecutrix. She was dragged in a room, where she was forced to consume liquor, while present appellant-(juvenile) and another accused were standing outside the room. Main accused Jitendra committed rape on the prosecutrix. Accordingly, case has been registered. Upon filing of challan, the case was committed for trial to the Sessions Court. The Sessions Court upon critical evaluation of the evidence placed on record has convicted and sentenced the appellant as referred above. Learned counsel for the appellant at the first instance fairly submits that the appellant (juvenile) has already suffered the jail incarceration for almost three years. There is no allegation of either violating the personal liberty of the prosecutrix or committing rape. Instead, the sole allegation against him is that he entered the house and was standing outside the room, where she was sexually abused by the main accused Jitendra. As such the conviction of the appellant under Section 376(D) of IPC and 5(G) and 6 of POCSO is fully unwarranted and based on surmises and conjecture. The appellant even otherwise, has no criminal antecedents. It is further submitted that co-accused Rohit has already been granted bail by this Court and the case of the present appellant is akin to his case. Hence, prays for suspension of sentence and grant of bail. Per contra, learned counsel for the respondent-State opposes the application supporting the order impugned with the submission that the appellant and two accused persons had entered the house of the prosecutrix with common intention of commission of rape. The active participation is well specific from the story of the prosecution and the evidence placed on record during trial. Hence, no exception can be taken in the matter of suspension of sentence and grant of bail. Upon hearing counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains from commenting upon rival contentions touching merits of the matter but looking to nature of allegation and since the appellant is having no criminal record, the application deserves to be allowed. Accordingly, we allow the application and it is directed that the jail sentence of the appellant - (juvenile) shall remain suspended and he be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond in the sum of Rs.2,00,000/- (Rupees Two Lakh only) with one solvent surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of the trial Court subject to verification of factum regarding deposit of fine amount. Appellant is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court on 23.11.2023 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed in this behalf with following further conditions:- (i) the concerned jail authorities are directed that before releasing the appellant, the medical examination of the appellant be conducted through the jail doctor and if it is prima facie found that she is having any symptoms of COVID-19, then the consequential follow up action or any further test required be undertaken immediately. If not, appellant shall be released on bail in terms of the conditions imposed in this order ; (ii) violation of conditions, State is free to apply for cancellation of bail. Accordingly, I.A. No.15174/2023 stands allowed and disposed of. Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of deciding the instant I.A. and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal.
