OTHER PRESENT: SRI.C.N.PRABHAKARAN-SENIOR PUBLIC PROSECUTOR THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 03.04.2019, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: Bail Appl..No. 124 of 2019 ORDER Apprehending his arrest, petitioner seeks anticipatory bail under Sec.438 of Cr.P.C. He is alleged to have committed offences punishable under Sec.354 of IPC, Sec.8 of the PoCSO Act and Sec.75 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act ( JJ Act for short). The police of Enathu police station in Pathanamthitta district has registered a case as crime no.1641/2018 against the petitioner. Prosecution case goes as follows: It all happened at around 1 p.m on 21.12.2018. The victim girl aged 16 years was returning from her school along with her friends. When they reached Karimpara junction, the petitioner who came on a scooter abused the girl. He caught her hand. When she objected, he slapped on her face twice. Heard Sri.K.Shaj, the learned counsel for the petitioner and Sri.C.N.Prabhakaran, the learned senior public prosecutor. It seems that Sec.75 of the JJ Act is out of question. Sec.75 provides punishment for cruelty to child. In order to attract Sec.75, the offender must be a person who is in actual charge of or control over the victim child. The prosecution has no such case. The learned counsel for the petitioner submits that catching the hand or slapping on the face do not attract the penal provisions in Sec.354 of IPC. It is also alleged that Sec.8 of the PoCSO Act is not attracted inasmuch as the acts alleged against the petitioner do not fall within the ambit of the definition of sexual assault contained in Sec.7 of the PoCSO Act. It is also the submission of the learned counsel that there is no allegation against the petitioner that he touched any parts of the body of the girl specifically referred to in Sec.7. It is also his submission that catching the hand and slapping on the face cannot be termed as an act with sexual intent. It is too premature to have a positive or negative finding on the arguments of the learned counsel. But his arguments cannot be totally ignored or brushed aside. I do not consider the present case to be one where custodial interrogation of the petitioner is an absolute must for an effective investigation of the case. Considering all these matters, I am inclined to grant him bail. The application is allowed. If arrested in connection with crime no.1641/2018 of Enathu police station, the petitioner shall be released on bail, after interrogation, on his executing a bond for Rs 75,000/- (seventy five thousand only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the investigating officer. The petitioner shall co-operate with the investigation. He shall make himself available for interrogation if so required by the investigating officer. He shall report to the investigating officer between 10 am and 11 am on every Saturday for a period of three months or till the filing of the final report, whichever is earlier. The petitioner shall not intimidate or try to influence witnesses. He shall not destroy or tamper with evidence. The court having jurisdiction is hereby empowered to cancel the bail in accordance with law if any of the conditions mentioned above is violated. If the petitioner surrenders before the court concerned, this order will cease to have effect and the said court will pass appropriate orders as if this order has not been passed. A.M.BABU 03/04/19 JUDGE

R BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR SMT.V.SREEJA THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING BEEN FINALLY HEARD ON 19-06-2018, THE COURT ON 25/6/2018 PASSED THE FOLLOWING: ORDER The accused in Crime No. 548/2018 of Ottappalam Police station for offences punishable under sections 7 & 8 of POCSO Act 2012 and under section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Care and Protection of Children Act 2015, are the petitioners herein. Admitted facts are as follows; The first petitioner had married the defacto complainant on 27/4/2009. Thereafter, they resided together for some time. The second petitioner is his father and the third petitioner is his mother. A girl child was born, who is aged 7 years now. Matrimonial dispute arose between the parties. It is stated that, on 5/9/2017, the wife left the matrimonial home. The child was in the custody of the petitioners till 15/9/2017, on which day the child was entrusted with the parents of the defacto complainant. The present complaint was laid by the wife alleging that the first petitioner had sexually abused the seven year old girl on few days between 5/9/2017 to 15/9/2017 at the matrimonial home and other places. Apprehending arrest, the petitioners herein have approached this court. The specific contention of the petitioners herein is that, the defacto complainant was a quarrelsome person and matrimonial relationship became incompatible. It was alleged that, the defacto complainant had developed a close intimacy with one doctor who was younger to her. She was found making secret audio and video calls to him over the mobile phone. When the relationship went beyond a limit, the husband intervened and she was warned. It was later understood that she continued to maintain even physical relationship with him. On being confronted with materials, she is stated to have abandoned the child and left the matrimonial home on 5/9/2017. Thereafter, the first petitioner herein entrusted the child to the defacto complainant and her parents, considering the education of the child. The first petitioner herein initiated matrimonial proceedings, including an application for custody of the child. The present complaint was filed belatedly raising absolutely false allegations with the intention of denying him the custody of the child. It was vehemently contended that, the first petitioner herein has not committed any sexual abuse on the minor girl and it was purposefully and belatedly set up. Annexure A1 is a copy of the petition in O.P.(HMA) No. 649/2017 dated 27/10/2017 filed by the first petitioner herein before the Family Court, Malappuram. He claimed divorce on the ground of adultery of the defacto complainant with the doctor, who was arrayed as the second respondent in that O.P. It was alleged therein that, she was having continuous physical relationship with that doctor and was caught with evidence. Annexure A2 is a copy of O.P.( G & W) No. 356/2018 filed by the first petitioner herein on 24/5/2018 before the Family Court, Malappuram claiming custody of the child. Thereafter, Crime was got registered by the wife at Bangalore as Crime No. 703/2017 on 11/12/2017 against the petitioners herein alleging matrimonial cruelty. The first petitioner sought bail which was granted by Annexure A3 order. It is seen that, she alleged that the petitioners herein committed acts of matrimonial cruelty and demanded dowry and thereby committed offences punishable under section 498A IPC and the provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The petitioner was granted anticipatory bail. Annexure A5 is a complaint filed by the defacto complainant before the State Commission for Protection of Child Child Rights of Kerala and Karnataka, with copies to the various authorities. It was alleged that, the father-in-law of the defacto complainant had made sexual advances towards her. She alleged that, in-laws had administered various medicines on her body. It was also alleged that, the child was physically assaulted by the petitioners during the period from 5/9/2017 to 15/9/2017. There is an allegation that, the grandfather used to beat her on her groin and grandmother had beaten the child with a chapathy rolling pin. Annexure A6 is the complaint No.20/2018 filed on 24/1/2018 by the defacto complainant under the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act. The above documents clearly show that, at no point of time earlier, the defacto complainant had a case that the child was sexually abused by the father. Even though physical assault is alleged against the petitioners, there was absolutely no reference anywhere that the child was subjected to sexual abuse by the father. It seems that, for the first time such a complaint is seen raised in the present crime(Crime No.548/2018 of Ottappalam Police station). Crime was thereupon registered for offences punishable under sections 7 & 8 of POCSO Act and Section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Care and Protection of Children Act 2015. The crux of the allegation in the FIS is that, during the period when the child was in the custody of the petitioners, the father of the child used to give her a bath. He used to undress her, remove his dress and give her bath. It was stated that in the course of bathing her, the first petitioner used to tickle her. The child has stated that, she did not like boys giving her bath. Pursuant to it, section 164 Cr.P.C.statement of the victim was also recorded, which is substantially in tune with FI statement. It is pertinent to note that the only allegation raised against the first petitioner is as above. Even if the entire statement made by the child is taken at its face value, crucial question that arises is whether the father had any sexual intent while giving the daughter a bath. This has to be appreciated in the background that the allegation comes only at a highly belated stage, when the father himself had sought custody of the child. No explanation is forthcoming for the delay in giving complaint. Hence, the question to be investigated by the police is only whether the first petitioner herein with sexual intention had committed any act. For that, custodial interrogation does not appear to be warranted. It is also clear that, in such a very strained matrimonial relationship a belated allegation of this nature has to be considered carefully and it may not be safe to order custodial interrogation. Having regard to the above, I am inclined to grant benefit of anticipatory bail to the petitioners herein subject to the following conditions: i). Petitioners shall appear before the investigating officer within ten days from today and shall undergo interrogation. Thereafter, if they are proposed to be arrested, they shall be released on bail on each of the petitioner executing a bond for a sum of Rs.50,000/-(Rupees fifty thousand only) with two sureties for the like sum each. ii). They shall appear before the Investigating Officer as and when called for and co-operate with the investigation. Anticipatory Bail Application is allowed.

S.C.No.4 of 2015 on the file of the learned Additional Sessions Judge, Fast Track Mahila Court, Nilgiris District at Udhagamandalam seeks suspension of his sentence of imprisonment. In the said Court, after trial, the trial Court convicted the accused under Section 7 read with Section 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (hereinafter POCSO Act) and sentenced him 3 years R.I. and fined him Rs.5,000/- and directed him to pay a compensation of Rs.1,00,000/-, i/d 2 years RI. The accused has been prosecuted for he having sexually abused her. The Trial Court believed her and construed his act as a sexual assault and thus convicted and sentenced him as stated above. The learned counsel for the petitioner/appellant would contend that the petitioner as well as the accused fancied each other. They fell in love. To distance him from her daughter, PW-1 had engineered this case. The prosecution version is the concocted brainchild of PW-1 in an unholistic alliance with the obliging police. The learned counsel for the petitioner further contended that in this case the two instances of occurrence have been projected. However, on this aspect, there is material contradictions as between the mother (P.W.1) and the daughter/P.W.2. It is PW-1 vs. PW-2. The learned counsel for the petitioner would also contend that top of it, there is material variation in the testimony of PW-2 before and during trial. Before trial before a Magistrate under Section 164 Cr.P.C. So also in her police statement. P.Ws.-2 and 1 were inconsistent as to the alleged date of occurrence, more particularly, PW-1 introduces a date, namely, 5.3.2015 which is nobody's case. 5.3.2015 was not uttered either by PW-2 nor prosecution. Thus, PW-1's version is a coloured version. In such circumstances, placing implicit reliance on the testimony of PWs-1 and 2 and inflict punishment upon the accused is too dangerous. Thus, there is prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. He will not run away. He has no bad history/antecedents. In the circumstances, he may be granted appeal bail. On the other hand, the learned Additional Public Prosecutor would submit that the Court can keep aside PW-1 because she is not the victim and focus its attention mainly on the victim/PW-2. Her evidence is crystal clear that the accused prayed on PW-2 like a vulture. He committed the inhuman act upon a minor child. Her solemn statement as to the sexual violence committed upon her. There is no significant reason for PW-1 as against the accused to implicate the accused risking the life and future of unmarried school going minor daughter. Very grave allegations are made as against the accused. There is no prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. This case is not a fit case for the grant of appeal bail. I have anxiously considered the rival submissions, perused the Trial Court's judgment and the piece of evidence referred to by both sides. In the facts and circumstances, now the question is whether the petitioner could be granted appeal bail under Section 389(1) Cr.P.C. Regular bail in a non-bailable offence in fit cases are being granted by the Magistrates under Section 437 Cr.P.C. While other Courts and the High Court exercises concurrent jurisdiction to grant bail in non-bailable cases under Section 439 Cr.P.C. The remand prisoners, under-trials could seek bail under the said provisions during pre-conviction stage of a criminal case. During that stage, it is pertinent to note that the presumption of innocence of an accused is intact because everyone is presumed to be innocent till the guilt alleged against the accused is proved beyond all reasonable doubts. However, once conviction is recorded, the said presumption is replaced by a Criminal Court judgment. Thereafter, also the conviction person can seek bail under Section 389 (1) Cr.P.C. Thus, the consideration for the grant of bail to an accused during the pre-conviction stage (before judgment) and post-conviction stage (after judgment) are different. So far as appeal bail under Section 389(1) Cr.P.C. is concerned, the Court has to find out is there any prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. While doing so, the Court should not indulge in meticulous examination of the evidence of the accused because the main appeal is not heard. It is still pending. To find out the prima facie case, the Trial Court has to refer to the findings recorded by the trial Court and the relevant evidence referred to. Further, it must also take into account the nature of the accusation made as against the accused. In view of the large scale violence committed upon the children, in 2012, the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (Act No.32 of 2012) has been enacted. It is a Central Act. It contains provisions ensuring confidentiality of the victim of the offence, her family details and also conducting of the trial in a child friendly atmosphere and it had also introduced a legal fiction as to the criminal propensity, mental faculty of the accused, through Sections 29 and 30(1) of the Act. However, under Section 30(2), the Act one's right of presumption of innocence until he is otherwise held guilty by legal evidence has been preserved. Thus, it is Indianised version of admixture of English Criminal Law (Common System of Law) and French Criminal Law (Continental System of Law). Now, in a prosecution launched under POCSO Act, age of the victim is very important because only upon the victim being below 18 years that she is a 'child' the stringent provisions of POCSO Act will apply and consent of the victim being immaterial under POCSO Act. POCSO Act is much more wider in scope in prosecuting an accused than prosecuting accused under Section 376 IPC. In this case, start of the offence was stated to be on 21.2.2015 in the house of PW-1, when her mother was away. During that time, PW-2 was studying VIII Standard in a school. It is stated that then she was 13 years old. Ex.P-3 School Certificate, Ex.P-8 Medical Certificate, Ex.P-9 age Certificate and the evidence of PW-7 School Headmaster and PW-5 Doctor beyond pale of any controversy establishes that at the time when the alleged occurrence took place, she was below 18 years. So she is a child within the meaning of Section 2(d) of POCSO Act. So the provisions of POCSO Act became applicable to this case. PW-2 is stated to be the victim of a sexual violence. Her evidence shall be treated as the evidence of an injured witness. If her evidence is consistent, cogent, unimpeachable unless there are acceptable reasons to implicate the accused, her evidence can be acted upon. The question of looking for corroboration for her evidence arises when her evidence appears to be murky. This is a rule of prudence and not a rule of law. Thus, corroboration cannot be insisted upon as a condition precedent to act on the testimony of a victim in a sexual violence case. But while appreciating their evidence, the Court must fathom out the reality of the situation and the truth of the allegations. While doing so, the Court cannot mistake every difference in evidence as a material contradiction. It cannot go blow out a contradiction beyond proportion. It cannot mistook a mole a mountain. In a sexual violence case, honour of two persons, namely, the victim as well as the accused is involved. When the allegations are very serious, the Court must be very serious of proving those allegations. Even to impute culpable mental state to the accused, there must be some material for the Court to have reason to believe the existence of such a fact (See Sections 29 and 30(2) of POCSO Act, 2012). Now, in this case, PW-2 the minor child had the countenance of the accused, a Book-Seller for the first time when he came to their house to market his books. PW-1 forewarned him not to visit again since there are ladies in her house. According to PW-2, on the fateful day, namely, on 21.2.2015, at about 2 p.m., while she was alone in her house, the accused came, pressed her breasts, pushed her to the bed, sexually abused her private parts by placing his private part. Subsequently, on 28.3.2015 around 2 p.m., when again the accused came to her house with similar motive, PW-2 raised alarm, the accused took to his heels, PW-1 came, PW-2 recounted the whole incident and also the earlier incident that took place on 21.2.2015. Thereafter, police complaint was lodged. Thereafter, medical examination was conducted and there was no presence of external injuries on her private part. It is pertinent to note that the actual physical violence was not on 28.3.2015. Even as per the version of PW-2, it was on 21.2.2015 and thus, by the time the medical examination was conducted more than a month had passed away, the evidence on her person had fade away. PW-2, being a child was under extreme trauma, normally a child like her, when placed in such grim situation, will not be forthcoming and will try to hide the shame. But, in this case, as per PW-2 when again the accused attempted to make her sexual assault on her, unable to put up with the shame, she cried and the accused was caught. Reading the evidence of PWs-2 and 1 and other witnesses and the complaint, the substratum of the case that the accused on the first occasion had sexually assaulted the victim has been brought out by the prosecution. The attempt of the defence to dilute the effect of the said evidence by clinging to some difference in the evidence of PWs-1 and 2 and in the statement of the victim girl recorded under Section 164 Cr.P.C. which are not so material and are not significant enough to shake the veracity of the testimony of the victim girl has not been shattered by this adventure of the defence which has become a misadventure. Further, there is no convincing reason or motive supported by any material or acceptable reason to view the evidence of PW-2 with a jaundiced eye. The nature of the allegations made as against the accused is very serious. Thus, the fallout is that there is no prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. Thus, I am not inclined to grant him appeal bail. In view of the foregoings, this petition is dismissed. However, it is made clear that the observations made in this order are only for the purpose of finding out a prima facie case to take a decision in this petition and it has nothing to do with the disposal of the main Criminal Appeal.

For Petitioners : Mr.K.Thenrajan For 1st Respondent : Mr.E.Raj Thilak Additional Public Prosecutor ORDER This Criminal Original Petition has been filed to call for the records in Crime No.76 of 2021 on the file of the 1st respondent and quash the same. On the complaint given by the 2nd respondent that his sister's daughter was missing from 12.12.2021, a case has been registered for girl missing in Crime No.76 of 2021 on the file of the T-14 Mangadu Police Station, Chennai 600 056 and subsequently the charges have been altered from girl missing to Sections 6 r/w 5J (ii) (i) POCSO Act, 2012. Today when the matter is taken up for hearing, it is submitted that the petitioner had married the victim girl as per Muslim rites and customs and the couple has a three months old infant born out of their marriage. It is further submitted that the de facto complainant who is the paternal uncle of the victim girl has also filed an affidavit by stating that in view of the marriage between the victim and the petitioner, he does not want to pursue the case. The petitioner, the defacto complainant, the victim girl and her mother were present before this Court and they were identified by the Police viz., Ms.K.Gracy, SSI, SRMC All Women Police Station, Mangadu. The 2nd respondent has produced the copy of the Aadhar Card. A joint compromise memo, dated 02.12.2022 has also been filed. The second respondent has stated that she affixed her signature without fear or coercion. The records would reveal that the date of birth of the victim girl is 03.06.2004 and she has attained majority. As it has been stated already, the marriage between the victim girl and the accused had taken place and they have constituted a family and become parents for a female child. In such circumstances, if the prosecution is allowed to continue, that will not serve any useful purpose and that will de-stabilize the family equilibrium of the petitioner and the victim. Even though the offences under POCSO Act are non-compoundable in nature, in the circumstances of the present case, I feel it is appropriate to take the cue from the principles laid down by the Hon’ble Supreme Court in the case of Parbatbhai Aahir Vs. State of Gujarat reported in AIR 2017 SC 4843. In the said case, in Paragraph 15, it has held as under: 15.The Broad Principles which emerge from the precedents on the subject, may be summarised in the following propositions: (i) Section 482 Cr.P.C preserves the inherent powers of the High Court to prevent an abuse of the process of any court or to secure the ends of justice. The provision does not confer new powers. It only recognises and preserves powers which inherent in the High Court. (ii) The invocation of the jurisdiction of the High Court to quash a first information report or a criminal proceeding on the ground that a settlement has been arrived at between the offender and the victim is not the same as the invocation of jurisdiction for the purpose of compounding an offence. While compounding an offence, the power of the court is governed by the provisions of Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. The power to quash under Section 482 is attracted even if the offence is non-compoundable. The petitioner who had married the victim girl, if subjected to trial that would affect the interest of the victim girl herself. In order to serve the ends of justice, I feel it is appropriate to quash the criminal proceedings against the petitioner by invoking the powers of this Court under Section 482 of Cr.P.C. In the result, this Criminal Original Petition stands allowed and as a sequel, the further proceedings in Crime No.76 of 2021 on the file of the 1strespondent, is quashed in terms of compromise. The terms of Joint Compromise Memo, dated 02.12.2022 shall form part of this Order.

ORDER
Dated this the 29th day of December 2020
The petitioner is the accused in SC.No.698/2019 before the Additional District and Sessions (POCSO) Court, Ernakulam. The accused is alleged to have committed offences under Section 376(2) of Indian Penal Code read with Section 6 and 5J(ii) of the POCSO Act, 2012. It is submitted by the learned counsel for the petitioner that petitioner and the 2nd respondent - the victim, were in love with each other and in their relationship, a child was even born. Photograph of the child along with the petitioner and the 2nd respondent is produced as Ann: A6. It is also pleaded that the crime No.342/2019 was registered on the basis of some misunderstanding and that, subsequent to the birth of the child, petitioner as well as the 2nd respondent have married each other. True copy of the marriage certificate issued by the marriage officer, Njarackal is produced as Ann: A4 and the birth certificate of the child is produced as Ann: A5. The prosecution alleges that on 26.1.2019, at 11.00 a.m, the petitioner committed rape on the victim and the victim became pregnant. The crime was registered on the basis of a complaint by the victim. According to the petitioner, the victim and the petitioner were involved in a romantic relationship and have even married. The complaint was filed on a total misunderstanding and no proper investigation was also carried out. It is contended that continuance of the proceedings is a sheer abuse of the process of Court and no purpose will be served other than waste of judicial time. Petitioner is only aged 25 years and taking into consideration the gravity of the offences alleged as well as the subsequent developments, especially the marriage between the petitioner and the 2nd respondent and the settlement arrived at there is no purpose in continuing the case. The settlement is reflected through Ann: A3 affidavit, wherein the victim as well as her parents have sworn to an affidavit, stating that they have no complaints or allegations against the petitioner and they have come into to good terms with each other and also that no purpose would be served in continuing the criminal proceedings. The learned Public Prosecutor on instructions, submits that the Police have taken the statement of the victim and have verified the veracity of the affidavit produced before this Court as Ann: A3. According to the learned prosecutor, the affidavit is genuine and can be acted upon. In view of the above circumstances, continuance of the proceedings in SC No.698/2019 before the Sessions Court, Ernakulam will only be an abuse of the process of Court. Since the matter has been settled by the parties and the petitioner has admittedly married the alleged victim, no evidence will be forthcoming to support the prosecution case. Continuance of the prosecution is therefore an abuse of process of Court and serves no purpose. In the result, the Crl.MC is allowed. Proceedings in SC.No.698/2019 on the files of the Additional District and Sessions (POCSO) Court, Ernakulam initiated as per Annexure A2 is quashed.
